Participation in intersession continued its downward spiral
this year, as registration fell once again, due in no small part
to the scarcity of course offerings. Homewood's academic
departments generously offered slighlty upwards of a dozen
supervised courses,. even inflating their benevolence with
numerous "independent study" listings. Each year,
Homewood's academic administrators ritualistically
pronounce disgust and amazement at the paucity of
intersession course offering, and pledge to make redress "if
not by this year, by next year, for sure," only to sit by
innocuously as the faculty produces a list of January courses
somehow smaller than the year before.
Dean of Arts and Sciences George E. Owen-for two years
running—has promised to exert the pressure required to
improve the academic quality of intersession, bestowing his
brown-eyed smile of benediction which always portends but
never delivers satisfaction. Perhaps wisely, the Academic
Council—and Owen as its effective head— has refrained from
establishing any teaching or departmental requirements
pertaining .to intersession, knowing that tyrannical
regulations will not alter men's wills. What is needed is a
simple willingness on the part of the faculty to maintain
intersession at a passable academic level, beneath which it
surely sank this year. But how to cultivate it?
Students have surely shown their ,interest in making the
program viable, though their enthusiasm is steadily on the
wane owing to the insulting dearth of qualified instruction.
That intersession is of great academic value to both the
faculty (surely the respite from the semesters provides
valuable research time) and the student should by now be a
commonplace. What we ask is that the faculty—rarely
motivated to dispense largesse to the undergraduates, even
during semesters—provide the modicum of cooperation
needed to make intersession viable.

Homewood's academic administrators ritualistically
pronounce disgust and amazement at the paucity of
intersession course offering, and pledge to make redress "if
not by this year, by next year, for sure," only to sit by
innocuously as the faculty produces a list of January courses
somehow smaller than the year before.
Dean of Arts and Sciences George E. Owen-for two years
running—has promised to exert the pressure required to
improve the academic quality of intersession, bestowing his
brown-eyed smile of benediction which always portends but
never delivers satisfaction. Perhaps wisely, the Academic
Council—and Owen as its effective head— has refrained from
establishing any teaching or departmental requirements
pertaining .to intersession, knowing that tyrannical
regulations will not alter men's wills. What is needed is a
simple willingness on the part of the faculty to maintain
intersession at a passable academic level, beneath which it
surely sank this year. But how to cultivate it?
Students have surely shown their ,interest in making the
program viable, though their enthusiasm is steadily on the
wane owing to the insulting dearth of qualified instruction.
That intersession is of great academic value to both the
faculty (surely the respite from the semesters provides
valuable research time) and the student should by now be a
commonplace. What we ask is that the faculty—rarely
motivated to dispense largesse to the undergraduates, even
during semesters—provide the modicum of cooperation
needed to make intersession viable.
